Planning¶

Collisions Utility¶

planning.collisions.get_avoidance(path, robot, obstacle)[source]¶

Detects if the proposed path intersects with the obstacle and calculates a nearby non-colliding position if it does.

Parameters:
  • path – A path object for the proposed movement, returned from models.py, in Robot:get_pass_path function
  • robot – The robot model moving to the ball
  • obstacle – Another PitchObject to avoid
Returns:

None, if the given obstacle doesn’t interfere with the path, or Path tuple containing new position, distance, and direction to travel to avoid the obstacle.
planning.collisions.get_boundary_path(robot, (x, y, displacement, theta), zone)[source]¶

Finds the first point inside the given zone that the movement pattern specified would result in.

Parameters:
  • robot – Robot model to extend movement from
  • x – Starting x-position of movement
  • y – Starting y-position of movement
  • displacement – Distance to travel each iteration
  • theta – The direction to move in
  • zone – The zone to stop movement in
Returns:

Tuple containing (x,y) positions of new point, distance between original and destination point, and angle of movement.
planning.collisions.get_interception(path, robot)[source]¶

Retrieves the travel direction and distance for the robot to intercept the given path of the ball.

Parameters:
  • path – A path object for the ball, returned from models.py, in planning.models.Robot.get_pass_path() function
  • robot – The Robot model
Returns:

A path tuple containing distance and direction to travel to intercept the ball path.
planning.collisions.get_path_to_point(robot, x, y)[source]¶

Retrieves a tuple indicating distance and angle between the robot and the given x,y point.

Parameters:
  • robot – The Robot model as the origin point
  • x – The destination x-position
  • y – The destination y-position
Returns:

A ‘path’ point including target x,y, distance to point, and direction to travel.

Models¶

class planning.models.Ball(x, y, angle, velocity)[source]¶

Bases: planning.models.PitchObject

The Ball is a simple PitchObject with predefined constants for dimensions. Represents our ball on the Pitch.

class planning.models.Goal(zone, x, y, angle)[source]¶

Bases: planning.models.PitchObject

The Goal class represents a goal in the Pitch and is simply a PitchObject with the zone property to allow querying of the goal’s zone.

zone[source]¶
Returns:Returns the zone this goal belongs to, as an integer index into planning.models.Pitch.zones()
class planning.models.Pitch(pitch_num)[source]¶

Bases: object

The Pitch class represents the full physical pitch and separates the pitch into zones based upon the croppings provided in croppings.json. Zones are specified as Polygon objects.

height[source]¶
is_within_bounds(robot, x, y)[source]¶

Convenience function, checks whether the given x,y position is within the given robot’s zone.

Parameters:
  • robot – The robot to check for containment
  • x – The target x position
  • y – The target y position
Returns:

True if the robot’s zone contains the given x,y position.
width[source]¶
zones[source]¶
Returns:The full list of zones available on this Pitch.
class planning.models.PitchObject(x, y, angle, velocity, width, length, height, angle_offset=0)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class that describes an abstract pitch object, representing dimensions, position, and movement attributes.

angle[source]¶
angle_offset[source]¶

Angle offset serves as a convenience for modifying any angle assigned to a PitchObject by the given amount.

Useful if the robot is at somewhat of an angle compared to a common reference object (i.e robot aligned differently to top-plate)

get_generic_polygon(width, length)[source]¶

Retrieves a polygon describing the generic shape of this object and rotated to correspond to our angle.

Parameters:
  • width – The robot width (front and rear dimensions)
  • length – The robot length (side dimensions)

class planning.models.Robot(zone, x, y, angle, velocity, width=30, length=45, height=10, angle_offset=0)[source]¶

Bases: planning.models.PitchObject

Robot class contains a model representing a Robot on the Pitch. Contains utility functions for using the Robot in the world.

can_catch_ball(ball)[source]¶
Returns:True if the ball’s center falls within the catcher area.
catcher[source]¶
Returns:Returns the catcher state, which should be one of [‘closed’, ‘open’]
catcher_area[source]¶

Calculates and returns a polygon representing the catcher area at the front of the robot. Rotates the polygon to the robot’s angle.

Returns:A Polygon.cPolygon.Polygon object.
get_direction_to_point(x, y)[source]¶
Returns:A tuple, containing:

[0] The displacement to the given x,y position [1] The angle between our robot and the given x,y position

get_displacement_to_point(x, y)[source]¶
Returns:The displacement between our robot’s center and the given x,y position.
get_pass_path(target)[source]¶

Calculates a polygon representing the passing ‘channel’ between our robot and the given target. This channel is a Polygon instance constructed between the front of our robot and the front of the target object.

Returns:A Polygon.cPolygon.Polygon instance containing the above defined area.
get_rotation_to_point(x, y)[source]¶
Returns:An angle to which this robot should rotate to be facing the given point, within the range [-pi,pi]
has_ball(ball)[source]¶
Returns:True if the ball is within the catcher area and our catcher is closed.
zone[source]¶
Returns:The zone this Robot belongs to, as an integer index into planning.models.Pitch.zones()

class planning.models.World(our_side, pitch_num)[source]¶

Bases: object

The World class is the high level model describing the entire world through the Pitch model and the PitchObjects contained within. Heavily passed around, this serves as the querying object for many different modules.

ball[source]¶
Returns:Returns the Ball model representing the ball in the world.
our_attacker[source]¶
Returns:Returns the attacker belonging to our side, as a Robot model.
our_defender[source]¶
Returns:Returns the defender belonging to our side, as a Robot model.
our_goal[source]¶
Returns:Returns a Goal model representing our goal on the Pitch.
pitch[source]¶
Returns:Returns the Pitch model this world contains.
their_attacker[source]¶
Returns:Returns the opposing attacker, as a Robot model.
their_defender[source]¶
Returns:Returns the opposing defender, as a Robot model.
their_goal[source]¶
Returns:Returns a Goal model representing the opposing goal on the Pitch.
update_positions(pos_dict)[source]¶

Receives a dictionary containing vectors for each of the PitchObjects in the scene and updates the models with the new positionings.

Parameters:pos_dict – A dictionary containing a vector for each of: [‘our_attacker’, ‘their_attacker’, ‘our_defender’, ‘their_defender’, ‘ball’]

class planning.strategies.AttackerDriveBy(world)[source]¶

Bases: planning.strategies.Strategy

Strategy where we drive forward and backwards, rotate and shoot.

Idea:
  1. Move to a location either in the UP or DOWN section, opposite to the location of the opposite defender
  2. If path is clear, proceed. Otherwise, switch sides.
  3. Rotate to face the goal
  4. Shoot
ALIGN_GOAL = 'ALIGN_GOAL'¶
DOWN = 'DOWN'¶
DRIVE = 'DRIVE'¶
FINISHED = 'FINISHED'¶
SHOOT = 'SHOOT'¶
STATES = ['DRIVE', 'ALIGN_GOAL', 'SHOOT', 'FINISHED']¶
UP = 'UP'¶
X_OFFSET = 70¶
Y_OFFSET = 100¶

class planning.strategies.AttackerScoreDynamic(world)[source]¶

Bases: planning.strategies.Strategy

Goal scoring tactic. Assumes it will be executed when the robot has grabbed the ball.

Outline:
  1. Position the robot closer to the border line.
  2. Move to aim into one corner of the goal.
  3. Re-rotate and aim into the other corner
  4. Shoot
Effectivness:
  • Only effective if their attacker is not standing on the white line close to us. They need to be at least 40px (the side facing us) from the division line between defender and attacker.
  • If opponent’s grabber is extended we may not get any leavway for scoring. This assumes that they effectively predict direction and optimize for maximum blocking area.
Maths:

  • When the opponent is defending ideally, we have about 15 degrees leaveway to score

  • Each ~5 pixels away from the ideal position we lose 2 degrees
    • Imprecision of 15px results in highly unprobable score in CONFUSE1.
    • Probability of scoring increases in CONFUSE2

  • Size of their grabber in extended position is not factored in

TODO:

  • Finish implementing

  • After CONFUSE1, check if we have a clear shot at the goal and shoot
    • Defender’s velocity should be taken into consideration
      • if velocity high, we are better off pulling off the CONFUSE2 part
      • if low, best to try to shoot as opponent’s vision/delay may not pickup the trick

  • Attempt to pick sides based on their robot velocity as well

  • Contigency
    • If both CONFUSE1 and CONFUSE2 fail, we may switch strategies or resort to a shot either UP or DOWN, based on their position.
CONFUSE1 = 'CONFUSE1'¶
CONFUSE2 = 'CONFUSE2'¶
DOWN = 'DOWN'¶
GOAL_CORNER_OFFSET = 55¶
GOAL_SIDES = ['UP', 'DOWN']¶
GRABBED = 'GRABBED'¶
POSITION = 'POSITION'¶
SHOOT = 'SHOOT'¶
SHOOTING_X_OFFSET = 85¶
STATES = ['GRABBED', 'POSITION', 'CONFUSE1', 'CONFUSE2', 'SHOOT']¶
UP = 'UP'¶
confuse_one()[source]¶

Pick a side and aim at it. Executed when we’ve reached the POSITION state.

confuse_two()[source]¶

Rotate to the other side and make them go ‘Wow, much rotate’.

generate()[source]¶

Pick an action based on current state.

position()[source]¶

Position the robot in the middle close to the goal. Angle does not matter. Executed initially when we’ve grabbed the ball and want to move.

shoot()[source]¶

Kick.

class planning.strategies.AttackerTurnScore(world)[source]¶

Bases: planning.strategies.Strategy

Move up and down the opponent’s goal line and suddenly turn 90 degrees and kick if the path is clear.

Go to the boundary of the attacker’s zone and align with the center of the goal line.

Go up an down the goal line waiting for the first opportunity to shoot.

class planning.strategies.DefenderBouncePass(world)[source]¶

Bases: planning.strategies.Strategy

Once the defender grabs the ball, move to the center of the zone and shoot towards the wall of the center of the opposite attacker zone, in order to reach our_attacker attacker zone.

DOWN = 'DOWN'¶
FINISHED = 'FINISHED'¶
POSITION = 'POSITION'¶
ROTATE = 'ROTATE'¶
SHOOT = 'SHOOT'¶
STATES = ['POSITION', 'ROTATE', 'SHOOT', 'FINISHED']¶
UP = 'UP'¶
position()[source]¶

Position the robot in the middle close to the goal. Angle does not matter. Executed initially when we’ve grabbed the ball and want to move.

rotate()[source]¶

Once the robot is in position, rotate to one side or the other in order to bounce the ball into the attacker zone. If one side is blocked by their attacker, turn 90 degrees and shoot to the other side.

shoot()[source]¶

Kick.

defend()[source]¶

If the ball is heading towards our goal at high velocity then don’t go directly into grabbing mode once the ball enters our zone. Try to match it’s y-coordinate as fast as possible.

Utilities¶

planning.utilities.calculate_motor_speed(displacement, angle, backwards_ok=False, careful=False)[source]¶

Simplistic view of calculating the speed: no modes or trying to be careful

planning.utilities.can_score(world, our_robot, their_goal, turn=0)[source]¶

Determines if our robot is facing, or would be if it turned the given amount, the opponent’s goal ready to score.

Parameters:
  • world – The world state
  • our_robot – The robot we’re checking facing direction for
  • their_goal – The goal we wish to shoot into
  • turn – [Default: 0], an optional turning offset that allows checking if we could score if we turned the given amount.
Returns:

True if the ball kicked from our facing direction, with turn offset if given, would result in the ball reaching the goal.
planning.utilities.has_matched(robot, x=None, y=None, angle=None, angle_threshold=0.3141592653589793, distance_threshold=15)[source]¶

Convenience function; checks if the given Robot is at the provided x,y position and/or angle to within the defined thresholds.

Parameters:
  • robot – The Robot to check accuracy of
  • x – The x-position to test, None if testing angle only
  • y – The y-position to test, None if testing angle only
  • angle – The angle to test, None if testing position only
  • angle_threshold – Threshold under which angle will be considered equal, [Default: ANGLE_MATCH_THRESHOLD]
  • distance_threshold – Threshold under which distance will be considered equal, [Default: DISTANCE_MATCH_THRESHOLD]
Returns:

True if the Robot has matched the desired thresholds to angle and distance.
planning.utilities.is_attacker_shot_blocked(world, our_attacker, their_defender)[source]¶

Check if our is blocked by the other robot by considering if the given robot is parallel to us within some threshold.

Parameters:
  • world – The world state to retrieve positions from
  • our_attacker – Our robot to check
  • their_defender – Their robot to check parallel state.
Returns:

True if the other robot is parallel to us within 40px threshold.
planning.utilities.is_shot_blocked(world, our_robot, their_robot)[source]¶

Convenience function for checking if one robot’s shot is blocked by another.

Parameters:
  • world – The world state to retrieve positions from
  • our_robot – The Robot model representing our robot
  • their_robot – The Robot model we wish to check is blocking
Returns:

True, if the shot is blocked by their Robot, False otherwise.
planning.utilities.predict_y_intersection(world, predict_for_x, robot, full_width=False, bounce=False)[source]¶

Calculates where the ball will be placed once it reaches the given x-coordinate if it were to be kicked by the robot passed in. Supports calculating the ball position even if it were bounced off the wall of the pitch.

Parameters:
  • world – The world model
  • predict_for_x – Which x-coordinate to extrapolate the ball’s y value for
  • robot – The robot to judge the kicking angle from
  • full_width – [Default: False]. If True, uses the full width of the pitch as the upper and lower y-values for bounce tests, calculated based on croppings of the pitch.
  • bounce – [Default: False]. If True, determines if the ball will bounce off the top/bottom of the Pitch before reaching x-position, and adjust for this.
Returns:

None if the robot is facing the wrong direction for the given x-position, or the predicted y position of the ball if successful.
